name: Universal Elimination (∀ Elim)
statement: If ∀x P(x) is true, then P(a) is true for any a.
philosophy: Allows application of a universal claim to specific instances.

name: Existential Introduction (∃ Intro)
statement: If P(a) is true for some a, then ∃x P(x) is true.
philosophy: Allows generalizing from a single instance to the existence of such instances.

name: Existential Elimination (∃ Elim)
statement: From ∃x P(x), assume P(c) and derive conclusion under that assumption.
philosophy: Permits reasoning from assumed existence by using a witness variable.

name: Universal Introduction (∀ Intro)
statement: If P(x) holds for arbitrary x, then ∀x P(x) holds.
philosophy: Generalizes from arbitrary cases to a universal statement, assuming x was not constrained.
